channel.description: An attempt at demistifying the quantum Fourier transform

description.p: Warm welcomes.
After more than a handful of failed attempts to start blogging, I‚Äôve built up enough courage to start writing, and I‚Äôm thrilled that untitld has seen the light of day.

Reasons for failure were manifold, among them being an unforgiving academic schedule. The kind that forbids one from partaking in extracurricular activities without worrying about losing time. But perhaps the most relevant to this blog was failure to find a motif for untitld. I gave a lot of thought about the objectives of untitld, attempting to narrow down possible topics of departure from ‚ÄúGround Zero‚Äù proved to be rather unfruitful and tiresome. I gave up altogether. However, this would later come up again in conversation with a friend.¬†

At some point during the conversation, I told my friend that I would be blogging soon. They paused and proceeded to ask ‚ÄúWhat will the blog be about?‚Äù. To their dismay, they were met with an eerie silence. "I thought blogs are supposed to have a theme‚Äô, they continued. Alas, for my friend and those that share the same views will be disappointed to hear that, this site will only fulfill the role of a core dump where I occasionally write, whenever and about whatever I please. I prefer this over what my friend was insinuating as the latter implies an agenda which goes against the eventual ethos of untitld.
untitld is still a work in progress with a lot of moving parts. As time goes on, I will include a comment section at the end of every subsequent blog post for feedback.
Thank you for being here. Until the next blog post.
Yours truly,
Unathi

Happy 3.14 Day, which also happens to be the day Albert Einstein was born ! So March 14 is irrationally (bad pun, I know) anticipated with much excitement by the science and mathematics communities alike. I will follow tradition, as I did last year and honor œÄ-day by recreating a visual representation of the digits of œÄ. The recreation will be a derivative of a 2013 œÄ-day poster by Martin Krzywinski found at http://mkweb.bcgsc.ca/pi/piday

The digits of œÄ were computed using the Chudnovsky algorithm. Due to the CPU-intensive nature of such a computation, I precomputed the digits and saved to them a .dat file for reuse. This is less time consuming than computing the digits every time when visualizing them (or if you write buggy programs like I do). Below is the python script that computes the n first digits of œÄ and saves as them to .dat file:
Since the digits will be displayed on a grid, the python script takes as input the dimensions of the grid, the number of rows and number of columns respectively.

Now that we have computed the n‚ÄÑ=‚ÄÑrc digits of œÄ, we want to visualize them. The visualization was done using scatter from matplotlib where the digits are laid out on a r‚ÄÖ√ó‚ÄÖc evenly-spaced meshgrid and the values of the digits are used to fill the colors of the points on the grid, these colors are taken from a discrete color map of size 10. The python script used to read the digits from a file and visualize them as explained above is as follows:
The visualizations below were for 23‚ÄÖ√ó‚ÄÖ23 and 31‚ÄÖ√ó‚ÄÖ31 grids (yes, I like primes) respectively.

What would be even more visually appealing is if we could connect the same-valued digits that are one point away from each other in either direction with edges as in the original poster. For example, for a 3 by 3 grid
In this case the 1s across the diagonal from the first row and second row will be connected with an edge. Similarly the 6s along the third row will be connected with an edge.

To do this, we need to able to find the indices of the connected clusters of numbers across the whole grid and use them to draw the edges between the corresponding grid points. Scouring around the internet, I found that such a computation is related to a concept in graph theory, which is the concept of connected components of an undirected graph. Finding the connected components of all the digits from 0‚ÄÖ‚àí‚ÄÖ9 across the grid will give us what we seek. At first sight, this seemed like a daunting task and I was apprehensive of whether a vanilla python implementation would be up to the task. However, it turns out this task is related to labeling components in a pixel array. Consider the following 3‚ÄÖ√ó‚ÄÖ3 pixel array.

The four 1s in the grid would deemed as a label/component and we would have only one component in the grid. The SciPy has a high performance C implementation, scipy.ndimage.label, to label the components and subsequently extract their indices. The single downfall of this method is that it also considers isolated groups (1 surrounded by 0s in all directions) as connected components. However, one can filter out isolated groups from the original array as done here. Putting this all together, we can produce the stunning visuals below. Here are the visualizations for 23‚ÄÖ√ó‚ÄÖ23 and 31‚ÄÖ√ó‚ÄÖ31 grids.
The updated source code and higher quality images can be found here. If you have comments or quarrels, reach out.

description.p: This post is the first iteration of an N-part series of blog posts aimed at attempting to understand some of the ideas behind Shor‚Äôs factoring algorithm. One such idea is that of the quantum Fourier transform (QFT), which will be the subject of inquiry here. I would strongly recommend familiarity with linear algebra and bra-ket notation. The following lecture notes on bra-ket notation should be sufficient.

The quantum Fourier transform is intimately related (same transform but different notations) to the ubiquitous discrete Fourier transform (DFT). The DFT converts a sequence of values, usually from some time-dependent function f(t) sampled at equidistant time intervals, into another sequence of values, sampled from a frequency-dependent function F(ŒΩ) at equidistant frequency intervals. The transformation from f(t) to F(ŒΩ) is the Fourier transform.
The discrete Fourier transform is a transformation ‚Ñ±‚ÄÑ:‚ÄÑ{xk}k‚ÄÑ=‚ÄÑ0N‚ÄÖ‚àí‚ÄÖ1‚ÄÑ‚Üí‚ÄÑ{yk}k‚ÄÑ=‚ÄÑ0N‚ÄÖ‚àí‚ÄÖ1, that maps a tuple of N complex-valued numbers

If the input values xk are real-valued, the discrete Fourier transform can be thought of as encoding of a discretized signal in amplitude and phase of a sin wave with frequencies $\nu_k = \frac{2\pi k}{N}$.

We see here that the action of UÃÇQFT is to encode the basis states, e.g |6‚ü©, by rotating the leftmost qubit along the line of latitude through $\frac{6}{2^3}$ revolutions, the middle qubit double that of the leftmost qubit, $\frac{6}{2^2}$ revolutions and the pattern continues. Turns out the states above also form an orthonormal basis, the sundial basis (or more appropriate Fourier basis) states, since UÃÇQFT is a norm preserving operation.

Thus by controlling R2 with qubit |x2‚ü© we can encode 2œÄ0.x1x2 in the phase, since whenever x2‚ÄÑ=‚ÄÑ0, R2 isn‚Äôt applied on |x1‚ü© leaving the phase 2œÄ0.x10 unmodified and whenever x2‚ÄÑ=‚ÄÑ1 we encode 2œÄ0.x11. dl.dd: I challenge the keen innanet dweller to convince themselves that the circuit below realizes UQFT for three qubits.

The pattern carries on to the general case, each qubit will have a Hadamard gate followed by a sequence of controlled phase shift gates, controlled by each of the qubits below the line ‚Äì i.e The line immediately below controls R2, the next one R3 and so on.

description.p: On the ith qubit, there‚Äôs a Hadamard followed by n‚ÄÖ‚àí‚ÄÖi controlled phase shift gates, controlled by the qubits that proceed it and there are n qubits in total.

p.span: $$ \begin{aligned} \displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{n} n + 1 - i &= \displaystyle\sum_{j=0}^{n-1} n - j \\ &= n(n+1)/2 \\ &= n^2/2 + n/2 \end{aligned} $$

description.p: The total number of gates thus scales polynomially ùí™(n2), a great improvement over the exponential scaling ùí™(n2n) of the classical analog.

The reduction in complexity of some problems, here the DFT, is one of the reasons why quantum computers hold promise (well, kinda of).3 In the iterations that follow, we will concern ourselves with quantum phase estimation and order-finding.
